name: Paulinho da Costa
description:
'''Paulo Roberto da Costa''', popularly known as '''Paulinho da Costa''' ({{IPA|pt|pawˈliɲu dɐ ˈkɔʃtɐ}}, born May 31, 1948), is a Brazilian [[percussion instrument|percussionist]]. Beginning his career as a [[samba music]]ian in Brazil, he moved to the United States in the early 1970s and worked with Brazilian bandleader [[Sérgio Mendes]]. He went on to perform with many American pop, rock and jazz musicians and participated in thousands of albums. ''[[DownBeat]]'' magazine call him "one of the most talented percussionists of our time." He played on such albums as [[Earth, Wind & Fire]]'s ''[[I Am (Earth, Wind & Fire album)|I Am]]'', [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s ''[[True Blue (Madonna album)|True Blue]]'', hit singles and movie soundtracks, including ''[[Dirty Dancing (soundtrack)|Dirty Dancing]]'' and ''[[Purple Rain (album)|Purple Rain]]'' among others. He has also performed on [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]]-award winning albums and singles including USA for Africa's ''[[We Are the World|"]]''[[We Are the World]]''"'' (Album of the Year and Song of the Year), [[Dionne Warwick]] & Friends' ''[[That's What Friends Are For|"]]''[[That's What Friends Are For]]''"'' (Song of the Year), [[Michael Jackson|Michael Jackson’s]] ''[[Thriller (album)|Thriller]]'' (Album of the Year), [[Celine Dion|Celine Dion's]] ''[[Let's Talk About Love]]'' (Album of the Year), the [[Saturday Night Fever (soundtrack)|''Saturday Night Fever'' soundtrack]] (Album of the Year), [[Anita Baker|Anita Baker's]] ''[[Giving You the Best That I Got (album)|Giving You the Best That I Got]]'' (Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female, Best R&B Song, Album of the Year, Song of the Year) [[Gloria Gaynor|Gloria Gaynor’s]] "[[I Will Survive]]" (Best Disco Recording), [[Rufus and Chaka Khan|Rufus and Chaka Khan’s]] "[[Ain't Nobody]]" (Best R&B Performance By A Duo Or Group With Vocal), [[Red Hot Chili Peppers|Red Hot Chili Peppers']] ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' (Best Rock Album), among others. He has also performed with [[Diana Krall]]. 

Da Costa plays over 200 instruments professionally, and has worked in a variety of [[music genre]]s including [[music of Brazil|Brazilian]], [[blues]], [[Christian music|Christian]], [[country music|country]], [[disco]], [[gospel music|gospel]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], [[jazz]], [[Latin American music|Latin]], [[pop music|pop]], [[rhythm and blues]], [[rock music|rock]], [[soul music|soul]], and [[world music]]. He was signed to [[Norman Granz]]'s [[Pablo Records]] for three of his solo albums, ''[[Agora (da Costa album)|Agora]]'', ''[[Happy People (Paulinho da Costa album)|Happy People]]'' and ''[[Sunrise (Paulinho da Costa album)|Sunrise]]'', as well as ''[[Breakdown (Paulinho da Costa album)|Breakdown]]''. da Costa received the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences' Most Valuable Player Award for three consecutive years. He also received the Musicians Emeritus Award.

Da Costa will receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in 2026, and is the first Brazilian-born entertainer to receive a star.
